Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Implications of Online Learning and Engagement Strategies with Elements of Competition on Women Students' Engagement and Fit with Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The underrepresentation of women in computer science has begun to garner attention in both popular culture and scholarly works due to shifts in demographics and concerns about remaining competitive in a globalized economy. Post-secondary programs are working to attract and retain women in computing fields in order to keep pace with industry demands for computing professionals. This has caused the computer science community to reflect on current educational practices, community culture, and university departmental climate. This project will use a cyberlearning environment known as SEP-CyLE (Software Engineering and Programming Cyberlearning Environment) to study the potential of using online learning and engagement strategies with elements of competition (known informally as gamification) as a strategy to enhance the learning, engagement, and identity development of women in computing. The intellectual merit of the project is its explicit exploration of gender in a cyber-learning environment. Despite the wealth of literature that explores gamification on learning there is no clear consensus on its effects on students by race and gender. Does gamification have value for improving female students learning and engagement in computer science courses? The results of this research will provide insight on gamification in student learning, identity development, and self-efficacy beliefs, and gender-fit in computer science. The results of this study will form the basis for more targeted learning and engagement strategies to attract and retain more women in computing fields.

The research activities consist of a mixed-methods study that explores the effects of gamification on self-efficacy beliefs and identity development for women and the usage patterns and learning outcomes for all students. The quantitative data will be disaggregated on the basis of race and gender to determine if there are differences in usage patterns and learning gains amongst participants of different races, genders, and intersections of race and gender. The results of the mixed-methods study will provide insight into both women's experiences within computer science and the implication of gamification on their learning and engagement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the proposed work we designed a mixed-methods gender study on the implications of gamification on student learning, identity development, and self-efficacy belief. As a part of this work we enhanced the data collection mechanisms in the Software Engineering and Programming Cyberlearning Environment (SEP-CyLE) to capture data necessary to investigate the following research questions - 1)  Are there differences in usage patterns between women and men in the use of SEP-CyLE? 2) Are there differences in learning gains between women and men in the use of SEP-CyLE? Additionally, we explored the experiences of women currently enrolled in SEP-CyLE-incorporated courses to understand the impact of gamification on a) conceptual understanding of learning objects, b) practical application of newly acquired knowledge, c) self-efficacy beliefs, and d) computer science identity development. In order to answer the following research questions - 1) How do women computer science students describe their experiences with online learning engagement strategies – gamification? 2)What impact does gamification have on computer science identity development of women? 3)What impact does gamification have on self-efficacy of women computer science students? 

 

Through this inquiry we were able to develop a stronger theoretical understanding of the effects of gamification on female computing students. As well as demonstrate through our quantitative analysis, a positive correlation between gamification and performance. However, there was no difference in this improvement between men and women, conflicting with other gender studies that found that there was a difference. This finding demonstrates that gamification may be beneficial to both genders in improving performance. Our qualitative analysis, we found that a majority of the female participants were apathetic or negative towards the gamification employed within SEP-CyLE, suggesting that the context and the combination of game elements should be carefully considered utilizing existing game design theories. Only a few individuals vocally stated that they enjoyed the gamified features of SEP-CyLE, suggesting that intrinsic motivation of individuals may play a role in their enjoyment. With regards to the research question around self-efficacy and computer science identity development (Women-CS fit), there was no qualitative evidence that gamification had an explicit impact on these constructs. Our convergent mixed-methods analysis converges on the fact that, while gamification may help improve performance in general, it is not an effective method in increasing interest and engagement of women in the field of computing. The findings make it clear that in-class experiences within introductory programming courses, however, do have an effect on identity development and overall persistence in computing. The women that participated in this study had an increased understanding of their computing identity salience, however, this was not due to gamification itself and can be most likely attributed to the acquisition of introductory programming knowledge from the class itself. 

This research study provides the basis for a more complete: theoretical understanding of gamification; understanding of the implication of gamification on women in computer science, computer science identity development, and self-efficacy. This insight into gamification has implications for computer science, engineering, and other disciplines in education.
